Hide and Seek?
Yea, it's pretty fun. I used to play it a quite a bit.
I'll explain in short.
You have 2 seekers, and 5 hiders.
Seekers are supposed to find, and kill hiders.
You have 5 lives as hider. When you have 5 deaths you have to afk in base, disconnect, or just walk in the outer circle.
Some champions like Teemo, Evelynn, kassadin, and rengar are banned.

Hiders are not allowed to kill seekers. And you can only use abilities that create terrain, apply any kind of cc, or grant mobility/health/defense.

Tank builds aren't allowed, you're supposed to build MS items.

The point is basically literally what it's called. Hide, and Seek
I'm going to miss hide and seek D:

Pretty much this. People might find it hard to believe, but Dominion WAS popular back in the days. Hell, we even had DominateDominion, a group dedicated to promoting the game mode and the matches between "higher ranked" players (so to speak, because of hidden ELO system) were epic. Unlike many might think, Dominion DOES have diversity, DOES have strategy and can lead to some amazing clashes when 2 or more veteran players meet on opposite sides. There were some gimmicky builds that eventually worked (movespeed Zilean anyone), but they were situational at best. Any team that had at least 1 player familiar with this kind of trick could easily neutralize it and, thus, punish the enemy team by steamrolling over it.

As someone who played it since launch (over 4k matches before they reseted the counter, God knows why), it is a really sad moment. I sincerely hope Riot will realize how bad of a move it is and, on a not so distante future, bring it back with the necessary updates and THE GODDAMN RANKED QUEUE WE'VE BEEN ASKING FOR WAY TOO LONG.

I miss so long ago when I could start spectating a game from when the Featured Game thing was new, and I'd occasionally get to see a high-ranked Dominion game. That was some of the funnest stuff to spectate because it was so different from SR. While someone like myself may only sort of understand what was going on, you could tell how well those top players, like Sauron, understood the mechanics of the map and how to use them to their fullest. It was so interesting because it was so different. 

I tend to love being a spectator and analyzing the action more than actually being in the action myself, so that probably doesn't help, unfortunately

It wasn't ever "popular", it died extremely quickly even when Riot tried fixing things. The fact the few people who cared about Dominion felt the need to try promoting it should've been a clear indicator that it wasn't popular in the first place. Other than when it was new que times were generally fairly long depending on the day and matches tended to be fairly one sided pretty often. Long que times was a general complaint back then and people had tried encouraging others to play it, although the general population had no interest in Dominion.

Although, it makes sense to remove it as a que, but I don't see why the map can't stay as an option for custom games.

>It wasn't ever "popular", it died extremely quickly even when Riot tried fixing things. The fact the few people who cared about Dominion felt the need to try promoting it should've been a clear indicator that it wasn't popular in the first place.

How do you think League got started in the first place? Fans promoted something they liked. You're comparing Dom's initial popularity to SR's then-current popularity, without considering that SR had both more time to become popular and more support from Riot. Riot only gave Dominion 2-4 months of small map tweaks before completely giving up on it.

>matches tended to be fairly one sided pretty often

Not nearly as bad as SR, considering Dom's mechanics. Even now Dom games tend to be closer than SR's snowballing mess.

>Although, it makes sense to remove it as a que, but I don't see why the map can't stay as an option for custom games.

Maintaining the Crystal Scar for custom games is roughly equivalent in resource costs to maintaining Dominion as a queue. Balancing would be the main difference, but there haven't been any Dominion-specific balance changes in over a year, so that part's moot. The map itself would still need bug fixes and likely a graphical update.

Riot themselves said people gave up on it extremely quickly, anyone that isn't biased and actually played Dominion between its release and now would know long que times were an issue for a very long time. It was also common to play with and against the same people for several matches in a row until people stopped playing for the day. I think it's funny you want to say SR is more one sided even though I rarely have SR games that end before surrender time is possible, meanwhile more than half my Dominion matches from 1 single day were heavily one sided due to the fact that my team completely out skilled the opposing team to the point I could have just been afk and my team would still win anyways, in fact most of the games where I played Lee I just played it as if it was TDM since my team never needed me for any of my wins. I'm sure it's a nice experience sitting in que for 5+ minutes for a match that lasted just as long or one where you felt you were completely unneeded. I had played 26 Dominion matches over 1 day and only lost 4 or so of them with every match but 2 being one sided.

Playing with and against the same people and long queue times aren't unheard of in SR either. They're expected when faced with a relatively small playerbase size. Dominion was popular in its own right; it just wasn't popular when compared to SR because SR had more time and opportunities to reach that level of playerbase.

Anecdotal evidence is fun! My experience is essentially opposite yours, as my Dominion games tend to be fairly close the entire game while my SR games typically heavily favor one side by surrender time.

>I'm sure it's a nice experience sitting in que for 5+ minutes for a match ... where you felt you were completely unneeded.

Yeah, that's why I don't like SR. Because I at least get interesting games playing Dominion instead of feeling either hopeless or unneeded playing SR.

Regardless, the fact is that the anti-snowballing measures in Dominion are much stronger than SR's. Stomps will still occur occasionally, but that happens regardless of game mode. The difference is that reduced snowballing makes playing from behind less frustrating and playing while ahead more challenging.

I think it's funny you think less than .5% of the people who even had access to Dominion playing it is "popular".

Even with potentially wider matchmaking ranges, games are still typically closer because the game mode itself discourages snowballing. I think it's impressive how you keep single-mindedly parroting the same explanation as if it's somehow convincing anyone.

You were saying my experiences were irrelevant even though it was stated to be an issue by Riot themselves. I also don't see what snowballing has to do with players of different skill level. You don't need snowballing through items for games to be absolutely one sided when there's massive skill difference. I've never even mentioned snowballing in any of my posts and stuck strictly to -skill- differences. You're the one who keeps repeating the same thing over and over with your biased experiences. Dominion was in fact -never- popular, it died immediately because the large majority preferred sr, which you know, Riot said as well. Unless you want to suggest Riot is lying, then by all means feel free to share your amazing data to prove Riot is making everything up.

Skill differences are issues with matchmaking, not issues with a game mode. Snowballing, on the other hand, is a game mode issue that affects the perception of skill differences. Riot's statement about matchmaking issues concerns Dom's current situation. This is an awkward situation to analyze because years of neglect have already driven off most of the playerbase, causing issues with matchmaking. Once again, this has to do with the matchmaking system; it's not some innate issue with Dominion.

As for the data, feel free to share yours as well. Riot said their data showed that the majority of League's playerbase preferred SR and thus Dominion is bad and flawed. My point is that Riot's misrepresenting the data because there's no analysis on *why* the majority preferred SR. Hell, if you look at my account, I regularly played SR in recent months/years and rarely played Dominion. The data would suggest that I too prefer SR over Dom. In actuality, I massively prefer Dom's gameplay over SR. As many other players have said over the years, it's certainly not a gameplay preference that I'm playing SR over Dominion.
